pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41282 
June 2008 
 
 
 
 
India: Knowledge Management for Enhanced 
Operational Effectiveness 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 10 June 2008) 
 
Currency Unit –  Indian rupee/s (Re/Rs) 
Re1.00 =  $0.0233 
$1.00 =  Rs42.89 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
EA  –  executing agency 
INRM  –  India Resident Mission 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors  –  Multisector- transport and communications, energy, agriculture and 
natural resources 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, governance, capacity development 
Subthemes  –  Fostering physical infrastructure development, financial and 
economic governance, institutional development 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  L. Jin, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Country Director  T. Kondo, India Resident Mission (INRM), SARD 
   
Team leader  P. Dayal, Principal Economist, INRM, SARD 
Team member  S. Viswanathan, Senior Social Economics Officer, INRM, SARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of India (the Government) has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) to support integration of knowledge management 
into various aspects of ADB operations in India to enhance their effectiveness. This has been 
the  outcome  of  consultations  between  the  Government  and  ADB,  and  the  positive 
demonstration effect provided by the Knowledge Management and Capacity Building TA1, 
which closes on 30 June 2008. Subsequent to consultations, ADB and the Government reached 
an agreement on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, and cost and 
financing arrangements for this follow-on TA.2 The design and monitoring framework for the TA 
is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB is committed to being a primary source of development knowledge in the Asia and 
Pacific region. To fulfill this mandate, it has adopted both external and internal approaches. The 
external  approaches  include  creation  of  knowledge  products,  knowledge  hubs,  knowledge 
partnership funds, and active promotion of public communications. Its internal approaches have 
focused on its various communities of practice, incentive systems, and eminent speaker forums. 
 
3.  This commitment to become a learning organization aims to improve the quality of ADB 
operations and enhance the capacity of developing member countries. To do this, knowledge 
management  activities  need  to  be  linked  closely  to  ADB’s  core  lending  and  nonlending 
processes. 3   ADB  operations  and  services  should  reside  in  finance,  knowledge,  and 
coordination.4 The long-term strategic framework (Strategy 2020)5 identifies helping developing 
countries gain knowledge as an important driver of change. 
 
4.  India is well positioned to take advantage of the knowledge revolution to accelerate 
growth and competitiveness, primarily because of the skill and labor capacity of its citizens and 
its information and communication technology capabilities.6 
 
5.  The TA is designed to support the strategic development focus of the Government and 
ADB  of  creating  an  enabling  environment  for  sustainable  and  inclusive  growth  through 
knowledge management, aimed at enhanced operational effectiveness. The ADB portfolio in 
India has aimed at poverty reduction and inclusive growth through support for creation of 
physical and social infrastructure. It has expanded to include pro-poor sectors such as rural 
roads, rural finance, and water resource development. There has also been increased focus on 
relatively poorer states or those with weaker institutional and financial capacities. With strategic 
changes in the country program, there is a strong need to analyze linkages and impacts to 
ensure enhanced operational efficiencies7.  
 
 
 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to India for Knowledge Management and Capacity Building. Manila (TA 4780-IND, 
for $2,000,000, approved on 17 April). 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 May 2008. 
3 ADB. 2007. Learning Lessons in ADB. Manila (March). 
4 ADB. 2008. Auditing the Lessons Architecture. Manila (February). 
5 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank 2008–2020. 
Manila (April). 
6 ADB.  2007.  Moving  Towards  Knowledge-Based  Economies:  Asian  Experiences.  Manila  (Technical  Note, 
September). 
7  ADB. 2003. Country Strategy and Program India: 2003-2006. Manila.

2   
6.  Capacity  development  through  knowledge  transfer  is  necessary  for  enhanced 
operational effectiveness. The TA will address the strongly felt needs of the Government and 
ensure client responsiveness by supporting capacity enhancement in poorer states with weaker 
capacities. In many of the ongoing projects, one of the causes cited for operational delays is the 
lack  of  adequate  information  and  understanding  of  ADB  policies  and  procedures  in  the 
executing agencies (EAs), including social safeguards, procurement, and consultant recruitment. 
The TA will address this gap.  
 
7.  The TA will be a sequel to the Knowledge Management and Capacity Building TA and 
the earlier Integrating Poverty Reduction in Programs and Projects TA8, which demonstrated 
the  importance  of  a  flexible  approach  and  systematic  capacity  development  for  enhanced 
development outcomes. Both these TA projects were supported under the United Kingdom 
Cooperation Fund (Poverty Focused) for Technical Assistance (Trust Fund).  
 
8.  An in-house assessment of the Knowledge Management and Capacity Building TA and 
feedback from the Government reveals that TA 4780 greatly added value to the knowledge 
management  process.  Portfolio  review  meetings  supported  under  TA  4780  have  helped 
enhance portfolio performance substantially in 2006 and 2007, increasing disbursements from 
$641 million in 2005 to $701 million in 2006 and about $1.4 billion in 2007. Many analytical 
studies (including key areas such as urban poverty) and publications have emerged out of TA 
4780. The conferences and seminars component supported dialogue and engagement with key 
government, civil society, and private sector stakeholders on development themes of current 
and emerging relevance including public-private partnerships in infrastructure development. 
Small-scale, innovative projects have been supported under the poverty reduction component. 
ADB has entered into knowledge partnerships with other donors.  ADB is partnering the United 
Nations solution exchange initiative in India and has supported the functioning of “communities 
of  practice”  on  the  themes  of  poverty,  health,  environment,  disaster  management,  and 
information  and  communication  technology  for  development.  ADB  also  entered  into  a 
partnership with the World Bank in India to support its small grants program, India Development 
Marketplace 2007, to finance grassroots initiatives for the protection and management of natural 
resources. Given the positive impacts on ADB’s India program and portfolio management, as 
well as the high priority attached to this TA by the Government during fact-finding, this TA is 
being processed as a sequel to Knowledge Management and Capacity Building TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected impact of the TA is to create an enabling environment for sustainable and 
inclusive growth through knowledge management and capacity enhancement. The outcome will 
be reflected in the enhanced operational effectiveness of ADB’s India operations from effective 
knowledge creation, dissemination, capacity enhancement, and partnerships. This creation and 
integration of knowledge will focus on key areas of operational relevance in the ADB India 
program such as transport, energy, urban infrastructure, financial sector, and water resources. 
Focus will be on sectors important for inclusive growth and poverty reduction as identified by the 
Government9 and those identified by ADB in Strategy 2020. It will also support knowledge 
management at the state level, especially in states where ADB has operations. Under capacity 
enhancement, the TA will support knowledge sharing activities, dissemination of best practices, 
and capacity development. 
                                                 
8 ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to India for Integrating Poverty Reduction in Programs and Projects. Manila (TA 
3880-IND approved in June, for $640,000). 
9 Planning Commission, Government of India. 2007. 11th Five Year Plan (2007–2012). New Delhi.

3
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will promote enhanced operational efficiency of ADB operations in India by 
supporting  the  following  components:  (i)  knowledge  creation,  (ii)  knowledge  dissemination, 
(iii) knowledge for improved operational effectiveness, and (iv) knowledge partnerships and 
networking. 
 
11.  The activities and outputs under these components will include the following: 
 
  1.  Knowledge Creation 
12.  Studies, Impact Assessments, Evaluation Studies, and Appraisals in Important 
Areas of Inclusive Growth and Operational Relevance. The TA will support undertaking of 
need-based analytical and sector studies, and impact assessments. These will be in the key 
operational sectors relating to the ADB program in India. The studies will include national and 
state level studies, desk reviews, and field studies. The TA will cover about 3–4 such studies 
with costing about $25,000–$30,000 each. The studies will be focused on the ongoing and 
future program of ADB in India, and will be carried out by accredited institutions or firms. The 
terms of reference for the proposed work and its documentation plan will be provided by the 
sector division requesting the work. A memorandum of understanding will be signed with each 
of the institutions undertaking the studies to ensure, among others, agreement on the terms of 
reference and manner of presentation of the outcomes of the study. Partnerships with research 
and knowledge-based institutions will be supported, as required, under this activity. Efforts will 
be made to identify operationally relevant reports for wider dissemination in coordination with 
ADB’s Department of External Relations. 
 
13.  Consulting Services to Provide Value Added to Knowledge Creation. Individual 
national consultants will be engaged over the period of the TA on a needs basis to provide 
specialized inputs in the operational sectors, states, and crosscutting themes.  
 
2.  Knowledge Dissemination 
14.  Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Other Knowledge-Sharing Activities. The 
TA will support conferences, seminars, and workshop events on a focused basis. These will be 
in areas of relevance for ADB operations in India. The relevance of the events will be clearly 
spelled out. Visibility for ADB and its partners will be aimed at, where feasible. Resource 
persons will be tasked to collate outcomes and highlights of various learning events for broader 
dissemination as deemed necessary.  
 
15.  Publications to Support Such Dissemination. Publication of studies undertaken both 
under the TA and by ADB, conference outcomes, good practices, and other material that will 
enhance value added and awareness through knowledge dissemination, will be considered for 
publication. The publications will be in keeping with ADB’s goals, and will receive the necessary 
no objection clearances from ADB’s Department of External Relations in accordance with ADB 
procedures.  
 
16.  Internal Knowledge Enhancement through Cross-Learning. To encourage creation 
and sharing of knowledge and experiences, events targeting knowledge enhancement among 
staff on key development and operational issues will be supported.  
 
3.  Knowledge for Enhanced Operational effectiveness 
 
17.  Capacity  Development  of  EAs  on  Important  Operational  Matters.  Capacity 
development under the TA will cover operational issues pertaining to both old and new EAs and

4   
states.  It  will  support  capacity  building  on  various  aspects  of  project  processing  and 
implementation, but it will be need-based and identified by the EA and ADB. The EAs/mission 
leaders  processing  project  preparatory  TA  projects  or  implementing  projects  may  provide 
feedback to the Government and the India Resident Mission (INRM) on identified capacity 
building requirements, and the advisory committee will decide.  
 
18.  Support  for  Portfolio  Reviews  and  Tripartite  Meetings  to  Ensure  Critical 
Knowledge Exchange on Operational Issues: Meetings and Retreats on Portfolio Matters. 
ADB operations in India have been expanding both in terms of new states and sectors. As a 
result,  several  operational  matters  emerge  that  need  to  be  discussed,  brainstormed,  and 
resolved. Meetings with various EAs in the sectors of ADB operations serve as an important 
cross-learning platform for agencies and states. About 4–5 such meetings and retreats are 
proposed to be held during the 2-year duration of the TA, averaging about $30,000 each.   
 
19.  Visit to Best Practice Sites (National, Regional, or International) for Learning by 
Seeing  Successful  Initiatives.  There  are  sector-related  and  state  level  experiences  from 
completed projects within the country, and experiences in the Asia region and internationally. 
The Government (central and state) greatly values such cross-learning. The TA will support 
hands-on  learning  through  site  visits  by  those  directly  concerned  with  project  design  and 
implementation. Sector specialists or mission leaders of the various ADB-supported ongoing 
and proposed projects will prepare requests for such site visits, which will add value to project 
design and implementation. Participating officials from EAs will be required to prepare and 
provide a two-page report on how they propose to operationalize the lessons from the study 
tours,  and  conduct  a  dissemination  seminar  for  other  members  in  the  EAs  and  sector 
departments. All study tour proposals will be endorsed by the advisory committee set up under 
the TA or by the country director of INRM. 
 
20.  Knowledge  Technologies  and  Enablers.  The  TA  will  improve  the  efficiency  of 
knowledge creation, processing, and sharing, through both hardware and software components. 
Such enablers have been created in ADB, including C-Cube (communication, coordination, and 
collaboration); creation of the skills database; document repositories; and portal development. 
These  help  in  real-time  sharing  of  information,  while  passwords  protect  access  to  ensure 
security. Other examples of enablers include online meeting and conference tools, and project 
management tools. 
 
  4.  Knowledge Partnerships and Networking 
 
21.  Select Innovative Projects for Inclusive Growth, including Civil Society Projects. 
The TA proposes to support innovative projects by developmental nongovernment organizations 
and community-based organizations, which promote inclusive growth. These projects will have 
linkages to ADB’s operations in India. The projects will typically be in the range of $10,000–
$20,000.  Requests  received  will  be  reviewed  based  on  relevance  to  the  stated  purpose. 
Selection will be endorsed by the country director of INRM and the advisory committee. 
 
22.  Knowledge Partnerships with Development Partners. In keeping with the goal of 
harmonization in knowledge creation and sharing, knowledge partnerships with development 
partners will be supported through memorandums of understanding. Such partnerships will 
address  various  aspects  of  knowledge  management,  and  seek  to  enhance  efficiencies  in 
knowledge  creation  and  sharing.  Instances  of  such  partnerships  under  the  Knowledge 
Management and Capacity Building TA are in paragraph 8.  
 
23.  Public-Private or Public-Community Partnership Pilots and Models. Partnerships 
with the private sector and communities are highly beneficial. Public-private partnerships help

5
supplement resources and combine strengths to achieve development goals. Partnerships with 
communities help in effective community needs assessments and resource mapping, which 
help  design  and  implement  inclusive  projects.  The  TA  hopes  to  support  innovative  pilot 
partnership projects for infrastructure creation or service delivery. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
24.  The total estimated cost of the TA is $1,250,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  Government  will  provide  counterpart 
contributions in kind estimated at $250,000. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
25.  The Department of Economic Affairs of the Government will be the EA for the TA. The 
EA will be a proactive partner in the implementation of this TA and it will consult various 
implementing agencies, as required and nominate staff for participation in the various capacity 
building events. INRM will coordinate overall implementation of the TA.   
 
26.  An advisory committee, headed by the country director of INRM and cochaired by the 
joint secretary of the Department of Economic Affairs, will be constituted. It will comprise ADB’s 
project officer, sector specialists at INRM, sector directors in the South Asia Department, and 
representatives  from  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and  the 
Economics Research Department, as necessary. The advisory committee will meet at least 
once every 6 months, with representatives from ADB headquarters joining via videoconference. 
To ensure a timely response to operational requirements, the approval mechanism will be as 
follows. For activities such as analytical work, impact assessments, and small grant projects that 
can be identified and planned in advance, the advisory committee will endorse inclusion of such 
proposals. The country director of INRM will be responsible for endorsement and approval of 
activities  such  as  workshops,  seminars,  and  conferences;  meetings  and  retreats;  learning 
events;  and  capacity  building.  No  objection  concurrence  of  the  EA  will  be  obtained  for 
recruitment of consultants. These approval mechanisms have been designed to ensure the 
timely response of the TA to various operational requirements.  
 
27.  Recruitment  of  Individual  Short-Term  National  Consultants.  Individual  national 
short-term  consultants  (3–4)  will  be  hired  on  a  need  basis,  depending  on  operational 
requirements. International expertise will be co-opted in the form of resource persons, as and 
when required. The short-term consultants engaged under the TA will be recruited by ADB in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
More information on consulting services is in Appendix 3.   
 
28.  The TA outputs will be spread over the period of implementation of the TA—from 1 July 
2008 to 30 June 2010. They will be disseminated through (i) study reports, (ii) publications, 
(iii) reports on study tours, (iv) reports on capacity building and relevance, (v) project reports on 
small grant activities, (vi) seminars within ADB, and (vii) briefs on the INRM website and/or 
South Asia Department intranet. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Knowledge Management for Enhanced Operational Effectiveness, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  National short-term individual consultants will be recruited to provide specialized inputs 
in the operational sectors, states, and crosscutting themes. The short-term consultants engaged 
under the technical assistance will be recruited by the Asian Development Bank in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). They will 
be hired on a needs basis, depending on operational requirements. The terms of reference for 
the short-term consultants will be provided by the sector division requesting the services.   
 
2.  International resource persons will be hired on a needs basis. Their involvement will be 
endorsed by the country director of the India Resident Mission. They will support documentation 
and dissemination of international best practices; support dissemination of best practices; and 
participate in technical assistance workshops, seminars, and conferences as required.
